Detailed Description

Defines a VRA file type.

The most frequently used implementations of interface this is BasicVRAFile. Most implementations that extend this class will only need to override the following methods: 

    close
    flush
    getFileLengthOS
    getFileLengthRW
    open
    read
    write

Basic copy constructor for the class.

vrt::BasicVRAFile::BasicVRAFile ( string  fname,
FileMode  fmode,
bool  isSetSize = false,
bool  isSetCRC = false,
bool  isStrict = false 
)

Creates a new instance for a local file on disk.

Parameters:
fname The file name.
fmode The mode to use when opening the file.
isSetSize Should the size be set on write? (ignored if read-only)
isSetCRC Should the CRC be set on write? (ignored if read-only)
isStrict Should strict packet checks be used on write?

Member Function Documentation

virtual void vrt::BasicVRAFile::close (  )  [virtual]

Closes this file and releases any system resources associated with it.

If the file is already closed then invoking this method has no effect.

Reimplemented from vrt::AbstractVRAFile.

virtual void vrt::BasicVRAFile::flush ( bool  force  )  [protected, virtual]

Flush the content to the disk.

Overriding classes should call super.flush(true) if they wish to make sure that the FileLength and CRC get updated.

Parameters:
force Force contents to be flushed, otherwise skip for now.

Reimplemented from vrt::AbstractVRAFile.

virtual int64_t vrt::BasicVRAFile::getFileLengthOS (  )  const [protected, virtual]

Gets the file length from the O/S or -1 if unknown.

Implements vrt::AbstractVRAFile.

virtual int64_t vrt::BasicVRAFile::getFileLengthRW (  )  const [protected, virtual]

Gets the read/write length.

This is the index of the last octet that has been read from or written to the file. This may either be the maximum value of the read/write pointer *OR* the size of the file if such is known prior to reading/writing.

Implements vrt::AbstractVRAFile.

virtual void vrt::BasicVRAFile::open (  )  [protected, virtual]

Opens the file.

Overriding classes should call super.open() once the file has been opened in order to ensure the header fields have been read in (if applicable) and initialized.

Reimplemented from vrt::AbstractVRAFile.

virtual int32_t vrt::BasicVRAFile::read ( int64_t  off,
void *  ptr,
int32_t  len 
) const [protected, virtual]

Reads from the file.

Parameters:
off File offset at which to begin reading.
ptr Pointer to the buffer to hold the data read in.
len The maximum number of octets to read.
Returns:
The number of octets actually read in.
Exceptions:
VRTException If the file is write-only.

Implements vrt::AbstractVRAFile.

virtual void vrt::BasicVRAFile::write ( int64_t  off,
void *  ptr,
int32_t  len,
bool  flush 
) [protected, virtual]

Writes to the file.

This should call flush(doFlush) following the write.

Parameters:
off File offset at which to begin writing.
ptr Pointer to the buffer containing the data to write.
len The number of octets to write.
flush Flush to disk? Setting this to false disables header updates and flushing to disk, even if required.
Exceptions:
VRTException If the file is read-only.

Implements vrt::AbstractVRAFile.
